The BA in Anthropology is an approved match to:

  • Anthropology (AA-T)
  • Global Studies (AA-T)
  • Law, Public Policy, and Society (AA-T)

• See the University Catalog for the full listing of degree requirements for this major.
  • See the Admissions website for transfer admission requirements/information.
  • See the International Education & Global Engagement website for international transfer academic qualifications.
  • See the Academic Advising Programs website for information on California Promise and Associate Degree for Transfer.
  • See the University Catalog for Credit by Exam information (AP, IB, CLEP).

Students select one course from any two of the following subfields of Anthropology:

  • Biological Anthropology
  • Archaeology
  • Cultural Anthropology
  • Museum Studies


The only subfield with lower division courses is the Cultural Anthropology subfield. There are also upper division courses available in the Cultural Anthropology subfield. All other requirements for this major are at the upper division level. See the University Catalog for the full listing of degree requirements.

general_texts: The BA in Art - Art Education Option is an approved match to the AA-T in Studio Arts.

If applying to the single subject credential program, see the additional course listing below:

  • CMST 131, POLS 155, and a Foreign Language course are required for the credential program.
  • The Foreign Language requirement can be met through General Education and High School World Language courses.


See the Languages and Cultures department articulation agreement for approved transfer equivalent Foreign Language courses.

More information on the Single Subject Credential Program can be obtained through the School of Education.

Professional education program requirements are governed by legislative action and approval of the California Commission on Teacher Credentialing. Requirements may change between catalogs. Please consult with your Art Education advisor.

  • Ceramics
  • Digital Media
  • Drawing
  • Glass Design
  • Painting

The student is to select 9 units from a single art studio group (emphasis) and an additional 9 units from any art studio group. In the Art Studio Group Prerequisite Courses section below, the student should carefully select courses based on the courses the student plans to take to meet this upper division art studio requirement. Please see the University Catalog for the upper division course listings as well as the full listing of degree requirements.

general_texts: Students interested in the Photography emphasis are required to take ARTS 240 and ARTS 241 as two of the three courses listed in the Art Studio Emphasis Prerequisite Courses section below.

The Art Studio Option has an upper division requirement where a student selects an Art Studio Emphasis. Students must select a single emphasis from the following groups:

  • Ceramics
  • Digital Media
  • Drawing
  • Glass Design
  • Painting
  • Photography
  • Printmaking
  • Sculpture


The courses listed in the Art Studio Emphasis Prerequisite Courses section below serve as prerequisite courses to the upper division Art Studio Emphasis courses. The student should carefully select these prerequisite courses based on the Art Studio Emphasis of choice. Please see the University Catalog for the upper division course listings as well as the full listing of degree requirements.

1. Students who declare themselves an art major in the Department of Art and Art History are placed in the BA program.
  2. After completion of the lower division option requirements below, students may apply for admission into the BFA, and in most instances, they will be able to apply their lower division Art (ARTS) and Art History (ARTH) coursework towards the BFA requirements.
  3. Advisors will clarify receiving credits toward the BFA. It is advisable to have taken upper division art studio courses in the area of your emphasis before applying to the BFA in Art Studio Option.
  4. A GPA of 3.0 or higher (in the major) is needed to apply to the program.
  5. Admission to the program is determined by a portfolio review.
  6. Students in the BFA Art Studio Option must maintain a GPA of 3.0 (in the major) in order to remain in the program.

A minimum of fourth-semester competency in an Asian language (e.g., JAPN 202) is required for Asian Studies majors.

  • Chico State offers courses in Japanese.
  • Students interested in an alternative Asian language, such as Chinese, Hindi, Korean, Vietnamese, Thai, or others, can fulfill the language requirement by taking the equivalent of four semesters of the language from an accredited program either in the United States or through study abroad.
  • Students who have prior proficiency should contact the department for placement information.

general_titles: Physical Science and life science substitute Courses
general_texts: In sections below where the student is directed to select courses and there is a note "Only lower division courses listed," upper division courses are also available. See the University Catalog for the full listing of degree requirements.

Physical Science Requirement:

  • The Chico State courses listed under the Physical Science area are all approved for GE areas 5A and 5C.
  • Transfer students who take the equivalent of PHYS/ASTR 100 with a Physics (PHYS) course may complete this requirement.
  • The courses listed for the Physical Science Substitute Courses may fulfill GE area 5A and may also fulfill GE area 5C. It is noted below the course if there is a lab component or not. The student should check ASSIST.org or with an advisor to confirm the GE status of the courses listed as approved substitutes.

Life Science Requirement:

  • The Chico State courses listed under the Life Science area are all approved for GE areas 5B and 5C.
  • The courses listed for the Life Science Substitute Courses may fulfill GE area 5B and may also fulfill GE area 5C. It is noted below the course if there is a lab component or not. The student should check ASSIST.org or with an advisor to confirm the GE status of the courses listed as approved substitutes.

The GE Area 5 Scientific Inquiry requirement states that one laboratory course (5C) associated with either the 5A or 5B course must be taken. If the student selects both courses from the lists of approved substitutes, the student must be careful to ensure the 5C laboratory requirement is fulfilled.

• This option satisfies all requirements for subject matter competency in physical education for students pursuing a single subject teaching credential after completing the Option in PETE, providing GPA standards are met (2.67 cumulative, or 2.75 in the major).
  • Consult with a Physical Education Teacher Education (PETE) advisor early for specific requirements and suggested electives that lead to supplementary authorizations to teach additional subjects in the state of California.
Standard first aid and cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) certification are required.
Basic computer literacy skills are required and may be met through select college courses (e.g. UNIV 101 or its transfer equivalents) or through prior experience.

This online, state-support degree completion program is ideal for students who have completed at least 60 units of lower-division credit and want to finish their bachelors degree. Transfer students who have completed lower-division GE and American Ideals/Institutions requirements can complete the program in four semesters. Students with more than 60 units of applicable transfer credit may complete sooner.

The Bachelor of Arts in Liberal Arts is a fully online program offering a broad multidisciplinary approach to earning a higher education degree. Students are exposed to courses across various areas of study at Chico State.

Student must choose four courses from four domains. The four domains are:

  1. Domain 1: Technology, Literature, and the Arts (Group 1)
  2. Domain 2: History, Society, and Power
  3. Domain 3: Food, Health, and the Environment (Group 2)
  4. Domain 4: Social Welfare, Human Development, and Community

The two domains with lower division courses are Domain 1: Technology, Literature, and the Arts and Domain 3: Food, Health, and the Environment. All other courses for this requirement are at the upper division level. See the University Catalog for the full listing of degree requirements.

The BA in Liberal Studies - General Option (Online Degree Completion) is an approved match to the AA-T in Elementary Teacher Education.

• Students who select this option must live outside of the city of Chico.
  • This is a degree completion program where lower division pre-approved equivalent courses are taken at community colleges or other four-year institutions.
  • The 45 units of upper-division major courses can be taken fully online from Chico State.
  • A total of 50 units must be taken from a four-year institution, 30 of which must be taken from Chico State to fulfill the university's residency requirement.
  • Only 70 units from community colleges can count toward the 120-unit BA degree requirement.
  • Online students are encouraged to contact an advisor early to have equivalents approved.
  • Some online courses are only offered once a year.
  • Students must contact their advisor each semester for mandatory advising.

This degree completion program is designed for students who have at least 60 units of lower division credit completed and are looking to finish their college requirements and bachelor's degree. The 60-unit program is offered entirely online and can be completed in four semesters (for students who have completed lower division GE and American Ideals/Institutions). Students entering with more than 60 units of applicable transferrable credit may complete sooner.
The BA in Multicultural and Gender Studies Online Degree Completion is an approved match to the AA-T in Social Justice Studies.

Students are strongly encouraged to complete one of the following Areas of Specialization. Not all Areas of Specialization include lower division coursework. See the University Catalog for a full listing of degree requirements.

  • American Indian Studies Specialization (listed below)
  • African American Studies Specialization
  • Intersectional Chicanx/Latinx Studies Specialization (listed below)
  • Women's Studies Specialization
  • Queer and Trans Studies Specialization

Students wishing to pursue other elective options should work with an Multicultural and Gender Studies advisor.


Students are encouraged to select the course in Group 1B that best supports their chosen Area of Specialization.

general_texts:
• Advising is required each semester for all music students.
  • Incoming students who wish to articulate units from another institution in theory, aural musicianship, or beginning piano classes must take the Placement Exam in those curriculum areas. Students who wish to receive units as credit only in the curricular areas listed above must take the Challenge Exam in those areas. (For students that believe they have the necessary skills and do not need to take the class in question). Students may only take the Challenge Exam for a class in a semester where they are already enrolled in that class. Consult with the department office with any questions.
  • Students wishing to be enrolled as a music major should contact the advisor in the option in which they are interested. The advisor will help you determine if your choice of major/option is appropriate. Consult the department website to locate the advisor of the option or contact the department office with any questions.
  • It is strongly suggested that students enrolled in studio instruction (MUSC 110/310) be concurrently enrolled in a performance ensemble (MUSC 411, 412, 413). Students who have completed their requirements in studio instruction MUST be concurrently enrolled in an ensemble to be qualified for additional studio instruction units.

general_texts:
• Advising is required each semester for all music students.
  • Incoming students who wish to articulate units from another institution in theory, aural musicianship, or beginning piano classes must take the Placement Exam in those curriculum areas. Students who wish to receive units as credit only in the curricular areas listed above must take the Challenge Exam in those areas. (For students that believe they have the necessary skills and do not need to take the class in question). Students may only take the Challenge Exam for a class in a semester where they are already enrolled in that class. Consult with the department office with any questions.
  • Students wishing to be enrolled as a music major should contact the advisor in the option in which they are interested. The advisor will help you determine if your choice of major/option is appropriate. Consult the department website to locate the advisor of the option or contact the department office with any questions.
  • It is strongly suggested that students enrolled in studio instruction (MUSC 110/310) be concurrently enrolled in a performance ensemble (MUSC 411, 412, 413). Students who have completed their requirements in studio instruction MUST be concurrently enrolled in an ensemble to be qualified for additional studio instruction units.

This major has approved GE modification(s). See below for information on how to apply these modification(s).

  • MUSC 304 (upper division: taken after transfer) is an approved major course substitution for Arts (3A).


These modifications apply to the Music Education Option only.

  • MUSC 302W (upper division: taken after transfer) is an approved major course substitution for Humanities (3B).

In sections below where the student is directed to select courses and there is a note "Only lower division courses listed," upper division courses are also available. See the University Catalog for the full listing of degree requirements.

• MUSC 110 is not an active course at Chico State but is being used as a placeholder to articulate California Community College (CCC) applied music courses not specifying a performing medium.
  • A student taking such a course may substitute the CCC course for the appropriate MUSC 110A-G course listed in the program requirements below based on the specific performing medium practiced in the CCC course.
  • The student will need to speak with a major advisor to ensure proper credit is awarded.
For courses taken for a letter grade, students must earn a grade of C- or higher.

general_titles: Prerequisites for admission to the nursing major
general_texts: The Pre-Nursing Core courses, or their transfer equivalents, must be completed before admission to the general option.

In sections below where the student is directed to select courses and there is a note "Only lower division courses listed," upper division courses are also available. See the University Catalog for the full listing of degree requirements.
The Concurrent Core courses are required, but may be taken prior to admission or concurrently with the first semester of the nursing program.

• The cumulative grade point average for all college-level work must be a minimum of 3.0.
  • The cumulative grade point average for the two science courses and the two GE Area 1 courses used to earn points on the supplemental nursing application must be a minimum of 3.0.
  • The cumulative grade point average for all eight nursing prerequisites, once completed, must be a minimum of 3.0.
  • All nursing prerequisites must be completed with grades of C or higher.
  • At the time of application, at least two courses from GE Area 1 and at least two prerequisite science courses must be completed, with the remaining courses in progress.
Admission to the General Option is a prerequisite for remaining course requirements.

• Only 40 students are admitted to the BSN program each semester.
  • In recent years there has been high student demand for this major.
  • Students interested in this program should apply to the University during the initial filing period of the admissions cycle (October 1November 30 for any fall semester; August 131 for any spring semester).
  • A supplemental nursing application must be submitted by March 1 for the fall semester and by October 1 for the spring semester.
  • Information on any current enrollment restrictions is available from the Admissions Office and from the School of Nursing.

general_titles: Prerequisites for Admission to the Option in General Dietetics
general_texts:
• See the University Catalog for the full listing of degree requirements for this major.
  • See the Admissions website for transfer admission requirements/information.
  • See the International Education & Global Engagement website for international transfer academic qualifications.
  • See the Academic Advising Programs website for information on California Promise and Associate Degree for Transfer.
  • See the University Catalog for Credit by Exam information (AP, IB, CLEP).
The BS in Nutrition and Food Sciences - General Dietetics Option is an approved match to the AS-T in Nutrition and Dietetics.

Clinical Nutrition is not a requirement of the General Dietetics. Only students preparing for advanced degrees or careers in nutrition research should complete the required units of the Option in General Dietetics and also complete the courses listed below (only one course at the lower division level), which include a Chemistry minor.

A supplemental dietetics application must be submitted by March 1.

A dietetics application is available from the Nutrition and Food Sciences (NFSC) Department office.

In addition to the application, students must provide:

  1. transcripts of all previous college or university level work,
  2. a resume,
  3. two letters of recommendation,
  4. one-page written personal statement about their career goals.

Applications are reviewed by a committee that ranks all applications for placement.

Students not selected for the option are encouraged to meet with a NFSC faculty advisor.

Students not selected may reapply once.

• All required courses must be passed with a grade of C or higher.
  • Progression in the option in general dietetics depends upon maintaining a cumulative grade point average of 2.75 and a grade of C or higher in all courses listed in the major core and in the option in general dietetics.
  • The following prerequisites must be completed with a grade of C or higher: BIOL 104, BIOL 211,  CHEM 107,  CHEM 108, MATH 105.

Our flexible online format allows students to balance their education with work and personal commitments, making it ideal for both traditional students and working professionals seeking career advancement.

Areas of Concentration (Group 2-17): Students are required to select one of the areas of concentration listed below. They must take 21 units (up to 9 units at the lower division level and 12 units REQUIRED at the upper division level) from one of the following concentrations to complete this requirement. It is highly recommended students reference the University Catalog to see the full listing of degree requirements.

  • Alternative Dispute Resolution: Only upper division courses in this area of concentration, none at the lower division level (no course listings below).
  • Anthropology: Six units available at the lower division level.
  • Asia: Nine units available at the lower division level.
  • California: People, Places and Cultures: Nine units available at the lower division level. There are 3 subgroups: Culture, People, and Places. People and Places subgroups have no lower division courses.
  • Career and Life Planning: Six units available at the lower division level.
  • Child Development: Carefully select courses to ensure the area of concentration upper division unit requirement is met. Nine units available at the lower division level.
  • Community Organizing for Social Change: Only upper division courses in this area of concentration, none at the lower division level (no course listings below).
  • Economics: Nine units available at the lower division level.
  • Environmental Planning: Three units available at the lower division level.
  • Environmental Studies: Only upper division courses in this area of concentration, none at the lower division level (no course listings below).
  • Family Relations: Nine units available at the lower division level.
  • Geography: Carefully select courses to ensure the area of concentration upper division unit requirement is met. Nine units available at the lower division level.
  • Gerontology: Six units available at the lower division level.
  • Health Science: Three units available at the lower division level.
  • History: See the University Catalog for History Area of Concentration requirements (no course listings below).
  • International Relations: Carefully select courses to ensure the area of concentration upper division unit requirement is met. Nine units available at the lower division level.
  • Multicultural and Gender Studies: Nine units available at the lower division level.
  • Political Science: Nine units available at the lower division level.
  • Psychology: Six units available at the lower division level.
  • Public Administration: Six units available at the lower division level.

general_titles: Prerequisites for Admission to the social work major
general_texts: The BA in Social Work is an approved match to the AA-T in Social Work and Human Services.

A grade of C or higher is required for all course work in the major and for progressing into the Professional Sequence. Progression in the Professional Sequence also depends on maintaining a cumulative and Chico State grade point average of 2.0 and completing all prior and current required courses.

• See the University Catalog for the full listing of degree requirements for this major.
  • See the Admissions website for transfer admission requirements/information.
  • See the International Education & Global Engagement website for international transfer academic qualifications.
  • See the Academic Advising Programs website for information on California Promise and Associate Degree for Transfer.
  • See the University Catalog for Credit by Exam information (AP, IB, CLEP).

• Achieved junior class standing, including transfer students with 60 transferable semester units;
  • Completed or have in progress 39 of the 43 required General Education units and the specific prerequisites;
  • Have a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.0 for both the traditional in-person or Distributed Learning programs;
  • Complete 60 hours of documented human service experience through the completion of a volunteer or paid position (i.e., volunteer, community service, service-learning, or employment). Human service-related experience might include a combination of current or past paid and/or unpaid jobs, service corps, internships, or volunteer work in various settings within your community. The completion of SWRK 170 includes 10 hours of service-learning or volunteer experience that count toward the 60 hours;
  • Completion of PSYC 101 and SOCI 100 with a grade of C or higher by the end of the fall semester of the applicant's junior year;
  • SWRK 170, SWRK 200, and SWRK 202 must be completed with a grade of C or higher by the end of the fall semester of the applicant's junior year;
  • Students need to complete their practicum education within the 18 Northern California counties of Butte, Colusa, Del Norte, Glenn, Humboldt, Lake, Lassen, Mendocino, Modoc, Nevada, Plumas, Shasta, Sierra, Siskiyou, Sutter, Tehama, Trinity, or Yuba.
  • If you have passed the above requirements with a C or higher you are eligible to apply for the Professional Sequence. Applications will be available on the social work website in August. Complete and return the application electronically to the Chico State School of Social Work by the deadline indicated.
  • Transfer students who plan to take prerequisites at other educational institutions must consult the BA Director, DL Coordinator, or DL Advisor to ensure they are enrolled in articulated equivalents to the prerequisite courses on the Chico campus. The BA Director, DL Coordinator, or DL Advisor is responsible for evaluating the transferability of all social work prerequisites not listed on the articulation agreements between Chico State and other units of the California State University, the University of California, and the California Community Colleges system. Refer to the School of Social Work website for information on articulated equivalents.
  • We are committed to your success and we are here to support you, so feel free to reach out to the BA Director with any questions.
